title: Hong Kong protests: Students stage rally outside chief executive's office â as it happened | World news | The Guardian
summary: us and china air differences on hong kong .
chinese state media describes 'threat ' from protests .
chris patten condemns handling of the protests .

documents.title: summary
text: we 're going to wrap up this live blog .
our colleagues in australia will have continued coverage shortly , to be found on our home page .
here 's a summary of where things stand : students and other protesters gathered outside the chief executive 's office in downtown hong kong to demand that cy leung resign by day 's end .
student leaders said they would occupy buildings if leung did not leave .
there were no clashes reported wednesday and only a little arguing .
leung showed no inclination of stepping down and in fact was said to be willing to wait out the protests for weeks or months , according to a reuters report .
the demonstrations drew what may have been their biggest crowds yet during the day wednesday , a public holiday .
thursday is a public holiday as well .
evening crowds were slightly smaller than the night before , the guardian 's tania branigan reported .
a chinese-language editorial in the official people 's daily warned of a threat to the personal safety of hong kong residents if the protests continue .
chinese foreign minister wang yi met his us counterpart in washington wednesday and said the protests are china 's internal affairs .
john kerry ( @ johnkerry ) privileged to host lunch w/ # china 's fm wang yi at @ twitterid .
discussed our impt relationship , and # ebolaresponse , apec & hong kong a large rally took shape outside the chinese embassy in london in a show solidarity with the hong kong protesters .
see an interactive timeline of events before and during the protests .
read the previous blog summary .

on behalf of president obama and the people of the united states , i would like to extend our best wishes and congratulations to the people of the people 's republic of china as you celebrate your 65th national day on october 1 , begins a statement from us secretary of state john kerry released wednesday .
the statement does not go on to mention hong kong .
max fisher ( @ max fisher ) no mention of hong kong in kerry 's statement congratulating china on its national day .
probably right call actually .
kerry spoke about the situation in hong kong with his chinese counterpart in a meeting at the state department wednesday .
rounding the corner toward dawn , again , in hong kong : natasha khan ( @ natashakhanhk ) in # hongkong 's mong kok district , occupiers huddle around to talk politics at 5:09am .
# occupyhk
a sizeable rally remains at the china embassy in london : usman tayyab ( @ utayyab ) crowd thinning but still around 1500 here .
# umhk # globalforhk also see earlier .
a woman helps to collect garbage during a rally near the government headquarters in hong kong , wednesday , oct. 1 , 2014 .
yu/ap
the guardian 's lindesay irvine ( @ lindesayi ) is in mong kok , kowloon , across the bay from central hong kong , where protesters continued to hold the streets wednesday night .

lindesay writes : towards midnight the grid of narrow streets , closed by protesters , remained lively with small groups of mostly students wandering between a loose constellation of small public meetings with speakers addressing modest circles of curious listeners and reading and photographing the individual messages of solidarity pasted and taped to every available surface , ranging from the blunt ( fuck you china ) , to the warm ( i love you hong kong ) to the scatological , with numerous chalk cartoons on the empty tarmac de cy leung defecating .
a variety of improvised welfare stations were collecting and distributing parcels of cooling pads , first aid , food and the ubiquitous yellow ribbons .
cy leung graffito .

irvine the apparently relaxed scene of students patching together an occupation in solidarity with the central protests was being watched with some apprehension by david kc , an older man who remembered coming out to protest in the wake of tiananmen square .

beijing will tolerate it for a few more days , he guessed , but by next week , once the city would normally have returned to a regular working week , he did not expect the current restraint with no uniformed police visible to last .
a 19-year-old student told me that she and her friends were expecting to be out all night .
she did not give her name , but said they were not worried : not really .
we just want our rights .
xiya , another 19-year-old manning one of the welfare stations , was upbeat about the scene of polite defiance : we 're all helping each other .
another student who did not give her name , said the apparent lighthearted mood was misleading , and her words were echoed by another of the notes and posters : this is a protest , not a mardi gras .
please be solemn .
please be solemn .
a sign in mong kok , kowloon , 1 october 2014 .
irvine
rally in london : eli friedman ( @ elidfriedman ) this is # occupyhk in london !
via @ twitterid
protesters face off with police as they block the entrance to the chief executive 's office on october 2 , 2014 in hong kong .
mcgrath/getty images

here 's a recent submission to guardianwitness , a place for readers to upload photos , videos and text pertaining to the hong kong protests : freedom hong kong bus abandoned bus becomes posting point for people 's wishes sent via guardian witness by chinesemovies 1 october 2014 , 13:28

documents.title: summary
text: as our live blog coverage continues , here 's a summary of where things stand : students and other protesters had gathered outside the chief executive 's office in admiralty and vowed to stay until cy leung returns friday .
they exchanged words with police but there were no reports of clashes .
the office is right next to the people 's liberation army barracks .
protesters said they would occupy buildings if leung had not agreed to resign by thursday night .
leung made no sign of acceding .
an anonymous source close to leung told reuters that the chief executive was willing to wait weeks or months for the protests to end .
a large rally in support of the hong kong protesters developed outside the chinese embassy in london wednesday , shutting down a road .
us secretary of state john kerry and chinese foreign minister wang yi met in washington wednesday and aired their differences on the protests .
wang said the protests are china 's internal affairs .
tens of thousands of protesters remained in the streets of hong kong in advance of day 2 of national day celebrations .
sky news has a camera on the large rally outside the chinese embassy in london .
the reporter , richard suchet , estimates the crowd in the thousands .
sky news tonight ( @ skynewstonight ) latest from outside the chinese embassy in london , where a large demonstration 's under way .
# hongkong
quartz has translated people 's daily editorial of wednesday that described a threat from the hong kong protests .
read the full editorial here .
for comparison 's sake there 's a translation of the 426 editorial , published before the tiananmen massacre , too .
occupy central åå¹³ä½ä¸­ ( @ oclphk ) for comparison , @ twitterid sets oct1 people'sdaily editorial on hk side by side w its 26/4/89 editorial on beijing protests

the central barracks of the chinese people 's liberation army in hong kong are right next door ( to the west : map ) to the chief executive 's office where students are staging a sit-in and vowing to stay until cy leung returns to work friday .
paul mozur ( @ paulmozur ) amazing this is happening so close to pla barracks .
protesters literally underneath the all seeing cameras of pla

documents.title: us and china air differences on hong kong
text: the top u.s. and chinese diplomats are publicly airing differences over the protests in hong kong , the associated press reports : secretary of state john kerry met wednesday at the state department with china 's foreign minister wang yi .
kerry said the u.s. supports the highest possible degree of autonomy in hong kong .
he hoped hong kong authorities will exercise restraint and allow the protesters to express their views peacefully .
wang said the protests are china 's internal affairs and called on other countries to respect its sovereignty .
he said no country would allow illegal acts violating public order .

students outside the chief executive 's office say they will wait for him to return to work friday , afp reports : benjamin haas æ¬e æ ( @ haasbenjamin ) protesters say they will wait outside cy leung 's office for him to return on friday to talk face to face # hongkongprotests the wall street journal is at the protest : isabella steger ( @ stegersaurus ) police w mic on a stage is `` provoking '' ppl ; `` do n't respond to their provocations '' says one protestor .

a bbc world correspondent tweets photos of a pro-occupy rally outside the chinese embassy in london : julia macfarlane ( @ juliamacfarlane ) protest now outside # china embassy in # london , demonstrators showing solidarity with # occupycentral in # hongkong

isabella steger of the wall street journal tweets that the scholarism student movement , some members of which are protesting outside the chief executive 's office in admiralty ( map ) , has warned members to prepare for police action , and agnes chow , a student leader , has been passing out face masks .
varsity cuhk ( @ varsitycuhk ) 500 protesters now blocking the entrance of the office of the chief executive at tim wa ave , aiming to stop cy from going to work .
there are no signs of clashes at the moment .

isabella steger ( @ stegersaurus ) police guard chief executives office earlier steger tweeted that student leader joshua wong had given a speech in admiralty calling on protesters to stay until friday at least .
about an hour ago i spoke with tania branigan ( @ taniabranigan ) in hong kong .
i think there were more people here in mid-afternoon than there were yesterday at mid-afternoon , she says , but the numbers appear to be lower now than they were at this point yesterday .
there are still tens of thousands of people here .

on the question of the leadership of the protests , tania says , i think one of the really things that is very interesting about this is it 's never really been about a leadership in a way : i think it seems like there are differing views among the people who have a semi-leadership role , but they 're very keen to stay united .
everybody is trying to figure out where this is going , and that includes the student leaders , and that includes occupy central , and it certainly includes all the people on the street .

a reuters reports quotes an anonymous government source with ties to [ cy ] leung as saying that leung appeared ready to allow the anger to subside , and would only intervene if there was looting or violence : unless there 's some chaotic situation , we wo n't send in riot police we hope this does n't happen , the source said .
we have to deal with it peacefully , even if it lasts weeks or months .
leung could not be immediately reached for comment .
weeks or months , the source said .

more great submissions from readers at the scene via guardianwitness , a place for you to upload photos , videos , text any documentation you 've made : admiralty protest site on wednesday night admiralty 01.10.14 sent via guardian witness by joseph koszary 1 october 2014 , 11:28 music has had a big part to play in the protests 29.09.14 admiralty sent via guardian witness by joseph koszary 1 october 2014 , 11:22 umbrella revolution , 3pm protestors open their umbrellas at exactly the same time at 3pm , to the raucous sound of applause .
sent via guardian witness by justin lim 1 october 2014 , 7:24

two protestors draw an umbrella on the pavement , as part of a pro-democracy sit-in known as occupy central ' , blocking traffic on yee wo street , an otherwise busy multi-lane thoroughfare in causeway bay , hong kong , on october 1 , 2014 .
schifres/getty images

i 've just spoken with tania branigan in hong kong , who tells me there seem to be slightly fewer people in the streets tonight ( it is almost midnight ) than there were last night , but the protests during the day wednesday seemed bigger than they had been tuesday .
tens of thousands of people remain in the streets , tania said , with a lot of activity on all sides .
i 'll post a transcript of our conversation with some audio shortly .

documents.title: summary
text: as our live blog coverage continues , here 's a summary of where things stand : large protests in downtown hong kong persisted into the night on wednesday on the first day of a two-day public holiday .
see an interactive timeline of events .

there were no new reports of clashes , despite the presence of tens of thousands in the streets and scattered official events to mark national day , the anniversary of the 1949 founding of the people 's republic of china .
student leaders described a deadline for hong kong chief executive cy leung to step down of today or tomorrow .
the students threatened to occupy government buildings .
leung , speaking at an official ceremony to mark national day , made only oblique reference to the protests , which he has sought to end .
a chinese-language editorial in the official people 's daily warned of a threat to the personal safety of hong kong residents if the protests continue .
the editorial also said a decision to restrict candidates for chief executive in 2017 elections had unshakable legal status and validity .
freer elections is a key demand of the protesters .
click here for a who 's who of the protest movement .

documents.title: chinese state media describes 'threat ' from protests
text: the state-line people 's daily on wednesday ran an editorial warning that the hong kong protests were disruptive and constitute a threat to the personal safety and property of hong kong 's population .

the south china morning post has a screen grab of the chinese-language editorial and translations of select lines , including one that seemed to discourage talk of reversing beijing 's august decision to vet candidates in the 2017 election of the chief executive : the commentary argued that the decision was made in accordance with the real conditions in hong kong , in the interest of safeguarding national sovereignty , security , development and to maintain the long-term prospering and stability of hong kong .
the decision had unshakable legal status and validity , the unidentified staff writer for the people 's daily argued .

hong kong-based journalist and educator ying chan said the editorial reflected the authoritative official position but was not quite comparable to an ominous editorial that foreran the tiananmen massacre , published on 4/26/89 ( read more on 426 here ) .

ying chan ( @ yingworld ) hardline people 's daily commentary bylined pd 's `` commentator , '' æ¬å ±è©è « å¡ reflecting authoritative official position ying chan ( @ yingworld ) yes , ominous , thought not quite 426 editorial rt @ twitterid : mt @ twitterid : ominous people 's daily commentary
the guardian 's tania branigan ( @ taniabranigan ) sends a snap .
despite the celebratory atmosphere , she notes , protesters stress this is a serious business : no party .
no karaoke .
fight for democracy .
branigan

news you can use : today 's chinese : liz carter ( @ withoutdoing ) today 's chinese : ä¹±ä¸åºè±e ( luã n shã¬ chå « yä « ng xing ) `` a chaotic world produces heroes '' it is in times of trouble that heroic individuals emerge .
a human rights watch china specialist looks ahead : maya wang çæ¾è² ( @ wang maya ) while things might look festive for # hongkong 's protests , this is just a lull .
protest leaders likely have to escalate to keep momentum .
ap has video footage of hong kong 's embattled chief executive , cy leung , getting heckled during his national day speech .

documents.title: chris patten condemns handling of the protests
text: the last british governor of hong kong , chris patten , has condemned the handling of the protests and accused china of breaching an agreement to uphold universal suffrage .

speaking on the bbc radio 4 's world at one patten said china 's proposal to vet candidates for chief executive amounted to a breach of what the china authorities promised hong kong and now they are reneging on that .
patten : i think this has been very very badly mishandled .
he said he hoped beijing was watching the protests despite censoring coverage of the developments to own its citizen .
i think we 've got to see dialogue replacing tear gas and pepper sprays , he told bbc radio .

patten , who oversaw the 1997 handover of the territory to china , said : i think in order to save face for beijing and for the hong kong government , the right thing to do is to embark on a new period of consultation , make it genuine consultation , because there are a lot of very moderate people on the pro-democracy side .

former governor chris patten at the 1997 hong kong handover ceremony turnley/peter turnley/corbis martin jacques points out that under british rule hong kong never enjoyed even a semblance of democracy .
here 's more video from the new front in the protest in the tsim sha tsui area , courtesy of reader chinesemovies via guardianwitness .
cy leung has until tomorrow to resign , according to student leader agnes chow .
the guardian 's tania branigan has sent through a longer audio clip of chow 's press conference earlier today .
chow was a little vague about the exact deadline but made it clear that students ' patience with leung had run out .
she said : we will have deadline for cy leung of today or tomorrow .
this is the deadline for cy leung to step down because we have already used lots of ways of telling cy leung our opinion including different protests .
so there is no negotiation between cy leung and us anymore we have already given him a lot of chance [ s ] to respond .
he should step down and that line will be tomorrow .
chow said she could n't predict when the protest movement would end because it was self motivated .
she said that if the authorities tried to use force again to disperse the protesters , they would bear a very heavy political risk .
she added : it will make more people angry and have a feeling of discontent towards this government .

asked by tania about the dangers of backlash from the hong kong community over the disruption caused by the protests , chow said the movement hope to contain the demonstrations to three areas of the city .
tom grundy ( @ tomgrundy ) student leader agnes chow calls for cy leung to step down today or tomorrow # occupycentral # umbrellarevolution

here 's a roundup of the latest developments : organisers of the growing pro-democracy protests have predicted that the numbers taking part will reach a new peak as numbers swelled on the eve of a holiday to mark china 's national day .
joshua wong , of scholarism , said : the numbers today will definitely be bigger than yesterday .
protests have continued to be peaceful to avoid giving the authorities a pretext for using more force .
despite fears of a crackdown , police have kept their distance , maintaining the cautious approach they 've adopted since an attempt to crush the protests by force on sunday night backfired .
student leaders have threatened to occupy government buildings unless hong kong 's chief executive , leung chun-ying resigns .

agnes chow said : if our chief executive and the central government do not respect and listen to the people 's opinion , we will consider different operating actions , including occupying other places like important government offices .
the protest movement has spread across victoria harbour to a new front .
demonstrators were filmed at a sit-in the tsim sha tsu tourist area .
a leading pro-beijing politician has branded the protesters demands unrealistic and urged them to calm down and end the disruption to the city .
starry lee , a member of the legislative council of hong kong for the democratic alliance , said : dialogue and communication is key to reach a way out .
protesters heckled hong kong 's beleaguered chief executive cy leung when he attended a flag-raising ceremony to mark china 's national day .
several members of one activist group , scholarism , attended the flag-raising and turned their backs as the chinese banner was lifted .
leung made only oblique references to the protests rocking his city in his official address .
he said that china 's move to allow a free vote for hong kong 's leadership , but vet the candidates , still represented democratic progress .
the protests comprise multiple organizations with many leaders and many protesters seem unaffiliated .
read a who 's who of the protest leadership and see our interactive timeline of the background the protests .
another protest leader has confirmed that if cy leung does n't resign by thursday protesters will start occupying government buildings , ap reports .

lester shum said at a news conference wednesday that the student leaders would welcome an opportunity to speak with a chinese central government official , but not chief executive leung chun-ying , insisting he must step down .
shum is the vice secretary of the hong kong federation of students , which has played a key role in organizing the street protests that started friday .

as we noted earlier shum 's fellow student leader agnes chow said : if our chief executive and the central government do not respect and listen to the people 's opinion , we will consider different operating actions , including occupying other places like important government offices .
shum and chow were speaking at the same press conference .
sarah charlton ( @ scharlt ) anges chow of @ twitterid and lester shum of @ twitterid1958 currently chatting to the world 's media outside gov hq
in britain the opposition has backed the government 's decision to recall china 's ambassador to london over the handling of the protests .
kerry mccarthy mp , labour 's shadow foreign office minister , said : as thousands of protesters continue to gather in hong kong , the situation on the ground remains a matter of deep concern .

given the heavy handed police response in recent days , the british government is right to seek urgent reassurances from china 's government regarding its commitment to the one country , two systems principle .
it is vital that hong kong is able to preserve the fundamental rights and freedoms of its people , including universal suffrage .
it 's clear that only a period of dialogue can now move hong kong forward , and i urge the chinese government and the pro-democracy protesters to engage constructively in that discussion .
a hong kong trade union leader and a veteran of the tiananmen square protests in beijing in 1989 has urged the authorities not to repeat the crackdown that crushed that movement .

lee cheuk-yan , one of the current protest leaders and an opposition member of the legislative council of hong kong , said the protesters were determined to stay peaceful to prevent a pretext for a violent put down .
speaking to sky news he said : we do n't want hong kong to repeat the very very painful history of the 1989 democracy movement when the communist party opened fire on the people .
we are protesting here very peacefully .
even when they are teargased they [ the protesters ] are very restrained .
they avoid all violence against the police .
the people of hong kong are trying to make sure there is no excuse for a further crackdown like what happened in back in 89 .
we can not predict the future , people are worried , but determined to fight on for democracy .
asked about britain 's decision to recall china 's ambassador over the protests , cheuk-yan said it is very very late for the british government to try to intervene in the crisis .
he added : when i was young we tried to fight for democracy from the british colonial government but we got nothing at that time .
and then after the handover the chinese government kept on denying the people of hong kong the right of democracy .
we welcome the british government saying they support us but it 's really late .
pro-democracy campaigner lee cheuk-yan during a protest in 2012 .
lopez/afp/getty images

documents.title: protest leader confirms plans to occupy government buildings
text: another defiant protest leader has insisted that the demonstrations will not end until cy leung stands down as chief executive and hong kong 's democratic rights are secured .
speaking to reporters including the guardian 's tania branigan , student leader agnes chow also confirmed that the movement is planning to occupy government buildings .
she said : the only way to stop the movement is that our chief executive , cy leung , should step down .
and also that hong kong people should enjoy really democratic and equal political rights in our future chief executive elections .

asked whether the organisers would be calling for a strike , she said : if our chief executive and the central government do not respect and listen to the people 's opinion , we will consider different operating actions , including occupying other places like important government offices .
thanks once again to hyperactive journalist tom grundy for the updates .
tom grundy ( @ tomgrundy ) student leader agnes chow calls for cy leung to step down today or tomorrow # occupycentral # umbrellarevolution
readers in hong kong have continued to submit updates and photos to the guardianwitness assignment on the protests .
here 's a selection of some of the latest : the umbrella revolution we went down with our son today who was born in hong kong .
it was remarkably friendly and well organised , with teams of people delivering water and collecting rubbish .

sent via guardian witness by davehongkong 1 october 2014 , 9:36 street sign in causeway bay the 689 refers to june 89 tiannamen square editor 's note : a reader has advised that the number 689/553 does not refer to the tiannamen square date but the number of votes that the chief executive from the community got elected by .

sent via guardian witness by neil rowcroft 1 october 2014 , 9:13 under the bridge on sunday night - relaxed 2 views under the bridge - see previous photo sent via guardian witness by chinesemovies 1 october 2014 , 5:35
there 's been another wedding protest .
as we mentioned yesterday these days no protest is complete without a marriage ceremony .
hong kong 's occupy newly-weds , vivian lo and ka sing fung , prompted a brief history of the protest marriage from amanda holpuch .
now another couple have taken to the barricades , according to this photo from afp .
a couple take wedding photographs in front of pro-democracy protesters during the third night of protests .
lopez/afp/getty images

documents.title: joshua wong predicts biggest demo yet
text: hong kong 's pro-democracy protests will hit their highest numbers yet as china celebrates its national day , the student leader who helped precipitate the demonstrations said , writes tania branigan .
joshua wong of scholarism said : the numbers today will definitely be bigger than yesterday .
we hope citizens will join the civil disobedience , will keep safe and will rely on the principle of non-violence .
we hope they can invite more of their friends and family members to voice their opinions on universal suffrage and [ their wish that ] cy leung should step down as soon as possible .
earlier he and other activists turned their backs in a symbolic gesture of protest as the flag was raised at the annual national day ceremony attended by the chief executive .
crowds in the core protest zone around government offices at admiralty had already soared into the tens of thousands by mid-afternoon .
a new protest area also sprang up in tsim sha tsui .
student pro-democracy group scholarism convenor joshua wong makes a gesture at the flag raising ceremony .
kwan/getty images

documents.title: protests spreads to new front
text: video footage and photographs have emerged of the protests spreading across the victoria harbour to a new front - the tsim sha tsu area of the city .
jasmine siu ( @ jasmine siu ) blockades at tsim sha tsui # occupycentral # umbrellamovement austin ramzy ( @ austinramzy ) a few more critics speaking out in tsim sha tsui .
the area , also known as tst is a tourist hub known for its museums .
the images confirms what tania branigan reported earlier in an audio update .
we have seen a new protest front open up in the tst area .
there 's a sense of the protests spreading even further , she said .

documents.title: leung heckled by protest leader
text: protesters heckled hong kong 's beleaguered chief executive leung chun-ying when he attended the flag-raising ceremony , according to ap .

the protesters , upset that chief executive leung chun-ying has refused to meet them , have threatened to expand their demonstrations unless he resigns and the chinese leadership agrees to broader electoral reforms .
as he spoke later to a group of dignitaries , pro-democracy lawmaker leung kwok-hung shouted for him to step down before he was bundled away by security .
local councillor paul zimmerman held up a yellow umbrella .
the umbrella has become a symbol of the nonviolent civil disobedience movement because it has been used by protesters to deflect police pepper spray .
i 'm here today with the yellow umbrella because it stands against the shooting of tear gas at the children of hong kong .
i think we have destroyed the values of hong kong earlier this weekend by shooting tear gas at children , zimmerman said .
leung 's rejection of the student demands dashed hopes for a quick resolution of the standoff that has blocked city streets and forced some schools and offices to close .
it was not clear what the demonstrators plan to do next .
there were no immediate official statements from the protesters .
university students are already boycotting classes , and other options include widening the protests , pushing for a labour strike and occupying a government building .

chinese president xi jinping , who has taken a hard line against any perceived threat to the communist party 's hold on power , vowed in a national day speech to steadfastly safeguard hong kong 's prosperity and stability .
radical legislator leung kwok-hung , also known as long hair , joins pro-democracy demonstrators as they gather near a ceremony marking china 's 65th national day in hong kong .
lopez/afp/getty images hkdemonow ( @ hkdemonow ) at the national day reception , paul zimmerman wore a yellow ribbon and held up a yellow umbrella amid the crowds .

documents.title: protesters urged to 'calm down ' and drop 'unrealistic ' demands
text: a leading pro-beijing politician in hong kong has branded the protesters demands unrealistic and urged them to calm down and end the disruption to the city .
speaking to the bbc 's world service starry lee complained that demonstrators had but the government in a virtually impossible position .

lee , a member of the legislative council of hong kong for the democratic alliance , said : hong kong now is in a very difficult position because the demands or request made by the movement 's organisers are unrealistic .
they are asking the npc [ national people 's congress ] to drop the decision that they have just made .
and they would like the npc to apologise to hong kong people and they would like to see the resignation of most of the government officials .
for the first two [ demands ] it is out of the authority of the special administration government .
she urged the protesters to calm down and suggested the demonstrations should switch to hong kong 's public parks .
we do n't want to damage hong kong .
every people have to calm down now and think of a way out .
i would like the administration to open up some of the parks or space that is less disruptive and persuade the people to move in to continue their demonstrations .
lee also called for dialogue between the protesters and the government .
everyone has to understand the other 's position .
dialogue and communication is key to reach a way out , she said .
lee was asked by a protester whether the authorities had made the democratic demands of the people of hong kong clear to beijing .
she replied : oh yes of course .
during the consultation period [ on the elections for 2017 ] we definitely expressed what we have heard from the general public .
universal suffrage of hong kong can be achieved by having , first the consensus of the hong kong people .
second is the consensus of two-thirds of legislative councillors and third is the approval of the central authority .
and the central authority has set out its framework .
if we ca n't accept that we can veto that .
we have expressed clearly what hong kong people want .
they [ beijing ] know it very well .
wikitedium ( @ wikitedium ) starry lee : member of legislative council of hong kong representing the constituency of kowloon west .
the public face of the protest movement , benny tai yiu-ting , has spoken of his mixed emotions at the scale of the demonstrations .
speaking to bbc world service tai , a 50 law professor , said he was heartened by the level of support for those wanting democracy .
but he said was sorry that it took the firing of teargas to prompt so many to turn out .
he said : at some point i feel sad that has caused all these people coming here was the teargas that our government has put to our own people .
so its very mixed that 's my feeling .
activist benny tai , co-founder of the occupy central movement , speaks to the media at a protest outside government offices in hong kong .
ogle/afp/getty images
the guardian 's graphics and data teams have put together a useful and great-looking interactive timeline of the background to the occupy central protest movement .
hong kong timeline

documents.title: summary
text: i 'm about to hand over our live coverage to my colleague matthew weaver in london .

here 's where things stand : crowds are steadily building in downtown hong kong for the fourth consecutive evening of pro-democracy protests , which continued throughout wednesday 's national day public holiday .
despite fears of a crackdown , police have kept their distance , maintaining the cautious approach they 've adopted since an attempt to crush the protests by force on sunday night backfired .
official national day events such as the flag-raising and the address by chief executive cy leung passed without incident .
there were fears they could be come a flashpoint for clashes between protestors and authorities .
several members of one activist group , scholarism , attended the flag-raising but turned their backs as the chinese banner was lifted .

the guardian 's china correspondent tania branigan says the momentum is with the protesters ahead renewed demonstrations in the next few hours , and that the chinese government will be reluctant to have images of a security crackdown marring its national day .
listen to her audio update here .

leung made only oblique references to the protests rocking his city in his official address , saying that china 's move to allow a free vote for hong kong 's leadership , but vet the candidates , still represented democratic progress .
his resignation is a key demand of the student movements leading the protests .
supporters of hong kong 's pro-democracy movement rallied around the world in solidarity with the tens of thousands gathered in downtown hong kong .
see a gallery of readers ' of the historic protests .
the protests comprise multiple organizations with many leaders and many protesters seem unaffiliated .
read a who 's who of the protest leadership .
when mainland chinese go overseas ( or into hong kong ) , the great firewall of china follows , abc news 's karson yiu writes .

karson yiu ( @ karsonwhy ) mainland tourists in # hongkong wo n't be able to read about the protest on their phones ( unless on wifi ) because china censors roaming data meanwhile , south china morning post columnist george chen reports that china 's tourism authority is trying to halt mainland tourism to hong kong for at least a week due to the protests .
george chen ( @ george chen ) breaking : china 's tourism authority orders local agents to halt group travel to hong kong for at least 1 week due to # occupycentral -sources

supporters of hong kong 's pro-democracy movement rallied in capital cities across australia today in solidarity with the tens of thousands gathered in downtown hong kong , my colleague melissa davey reports : as tens of thousands of occupy central pro-democracy protesters remain on the streets of hong kong , smaller groups of their allies around the world , including in australia , are holding demonstrations in support .

on wednesday afternoon around 40 people gathered outside the state library of victoria holding signs with slogans calling for hong kong leader leung chun-ying to step down and demanding freedom and peace .
in brisbane , people will gather in king george square at 4pm with umbrellas , which have become the symbol of the movement .
similar demonstrations took place around the country throughout the week , with the abc reporting that approximately 250 people gathered in perth on monday in front of the east perth consulate .

in sydney , demonstrators having been sticking hundreds of notes on the walls of hong kong house , while a separate solidarity action took place outside the city 's queen victoria building on monday .
read the full story here
china 's censors have gone into overdrive trying to keep this historic event out of the mainland press and off social media , as this chart , counting the number of censored posts on weibo , shows .

interestingly , the 25th anniversary of the tiananmen square massacre in june passed with only a small spike in censored posts - one utterly dwarfed by the events of the past few days , where more than 150 in every 10,000 posts have being censored .
carl bildt ( @ carlbildt ) worth noting the dramatic increase in net control in china since the start of the hong kong protests .

documents.title: second computer virus targeting hong kong protesters discovered
text: via reuters : cybersecurity researchers have uncovered a computer virus that spies on apple inc 's ios operating system for the iphone and ipad , and they believe it is targeting pro-democracy protesters in hong kong .

the malicious software , known as xsser , is capable of stealing text messages , photos , call logs , passwords and other data from apple mobile devices , researchers with lacoon mobile security said on tuesday .
they uncovered the spyware while investigating similar malware for google inc 's android operating system last week that also targeted hong kong protesters .
anonymous attackers spread the android spyware via whatsapp , sending malicious links to download the program , according to lacoon .
it is unclear how ios devices get infected with xsser , which is not disguised as an app .
lacoon chief executive michael shaulov told reuters that xsser is the most sophisticated malware used to date in any known cyberattack on ios users .
this is one the most interesting developments we have seen , he said .
it 's the first real indication that really sophisticated guys are shifting from infecting pcs or laptops to going after ios devices .
the code used to control that server is written in chinese .
the high quality of the campaign and the fact it is being used to target protesters suggests that it is coming from a sophisticated attacker in china , shaulov said .
it is the first time in history that you actually see an operationalized ios trojan that is attributed to some kind of chinese entity , he said .
a trojan is a term used by cyber researchers to describe malware that enters a device disguised as something harmless .
still , he said that his company 's research team has yet to identify any specific victims of the ios trojan .
lacoon said on its blog that it is possible the attackers might have deployed the trojan in other places , in addition to spying on pro-democracy protesters in hong kong .

it can cross borders easily , and is possibly being operated by a chinese-speaking entity to spy on individuals , foreign companies , or even entire governments , they said in a blog post describing their analysis .
it follows the discovery last week of a fraudulent android app , claiming to coordinate protest activity , that recorded audio on a user 's phone and took coordinates of their location .
tania branigan ( @ taniabranigan ) rt @ twitterid : this is almost too much rt @ twitterid : hk protests proving the world 's politest and cleanest .
hong kong 's clean-cut campaigners have been praised for cleaning up their litter each morning , recycling - even keeping off the grass where signs instruct .
now they 've been snapped sheltering officers from the same police force who tear-gassed them on sunday night .
a bit much , some say .
emily rauhala ( @ emilyrauhala ) # hongkong home affairs dept hosting national day extravaganza with clowns and `` showcase of prc achievements . ''

( via @ twitterid ) here 's a little more info on the national day extravaganza that hong kong authorities have planned for 4pm local time today , that might become a flashpoint for protests : to share the joy of the 65th anniversary with the public , the home affairs department will hold a national day extravaganza at victoria park from 2 pm to 6 pm , featuring interactive games , clown street performances , traditional art and craft demonstrations , a showcase of achievements of the people 's republic of china and a hong kong nostalgia zone .
the setting of the extravaganza , victoria park , sees protests each year on june 4 to commemorate the tiananmen square killings .
it was reported earlier than the number 689 being touted by demonstrators is a coded reference to the june 1989 tiananmen square massacre .

not so , says one of our readers , hongkongobserver : the 689 number will not be a reference to the events at tiananmen square in 1989 but will be a reference to the number of votes that hong kong 's wolf ' chief executive cy leung received when he was elected in the small-circle election - see below : e£ e³¥ç¡æ¶¼å®®è : taiwan 's ma ying-jeou was elected with 6.89 million votes .
hong kong 's cy leung was elected with 689 votes !
i 've just been talking to my colleague tania branigan , who is reporting from downtown hong kong .
she went along to this morning 's flag-raising ceremony , which she said members of the activist group scholarism attended , but turned their backs as the mainland 's banner was raised .
she says the lack of a heavy police presence was striking and that authorities were treating the demonstrators with caution .

while [ the chinese government ] certainly do n't want protests taking place on national day , equally they probably do n't want scenes of police wading into demonstrations firing off tear gas , she says .
demonstrators have gathered in another part of the city , tsim sha tsui , which is giving the social movement new momentum , she says .
there 's a sense of the protests spreading even further .
i began by asking tania to describe the mood at national day events in beijing this morning .

tom grundy ( @ tomgrundy ) steady stream of ppl arriving at the admiralty protest site # occupycentral many returned home during rain last night tom grundy , who is in hong kong , tweets that admiralty is beginning to fill up again , after an uneventful morning that some took as an opportunity to rest .
the pattern of these protests so far has been peaceful mornings followed by raucous demonstrations in the evening .
this morning 's flag-raising ceremony was also uneventful , but afp 's jerome taylor notes there are several more national day events planned that could see protesters face off against police .
tania branigan ( @ taniabranigan ) rt @ twitterid : hk authorities just announced plans for `` national day extravaganza '' in victoria park later today .
will protesters target ?

documents.title: dozens detained on mainland for supporting hong kong protests
text: the watchdog group chinese human rights defenders reports that dozens of activists have been detained on the chinese mainland for expressing support for the hong kong pro-democracy movement .
a number of chinese citizens have faced reprisals for supporting the protests for universal suffrage in hong kong .

the occupation of several areas in hong kong , including parts of its financial and political center , has inspired many chinese on the mainland and encouraged them to speak up for democracy , with many photos appearing on social media of activists holding signs in support of hong kong and demanding constitutional democracy for the territory .
police in china have harassed and warned activists in many cities , concerned that they may try to travel to hong kong or take to streets to protest .

it also details threats and harassment suffered by other activists : on september 30 , chongqing national security officers called activist xie dan ( è°¢ä¸¹ ) to say they were coming to his home to question him .
chongqing activist han liang ( e©è¯ ) was questioned by police in the early morning of september 30 , but has since returned home .
beijing activists han ying ( e©e¢ ) and guo guijun ( e­æ¡å ) were both visited by police at their homes late at night on september 30 .
police demanded entry but did not show any proper documentation and threatened to take them into custody , since the activists refused to open their doors .
their fate remains unclear at the time of this report .

in addition , national security officers from changyuan county in henan province threatened democracy activist guo chunping ( e­æ¥å¹³ ) after he sent a message on wechat , a chinese text messaging platform , in support of hong kong on september 29 .
an officer called guo and said he would be in danger if he did n't answer her questions .
among these seized was song ningsheng , who along with two others , posted photographs of himself holding up signs in support of the protests .
activist song ningsheng of jiangxi province was taken away by police for holding up signs in support of the hong kong protests .

my colleague tania branigan is taking in the scene at admiralty , where she 's met kenneth wong : the night shift at admiralty is looking forward to going home and getting some rest as the next wave of protestors arrives .
kenneth wong , a 24-year-old graduate , said : there was rain last night - all of us were wet through , so it was a hard decision to stay .
but we know the significance of the protests and the reasons we are here , so we had to stay .
we know it probably wo n't be solved in a few days .
we have a long journey but we have prepared psychologically .
i think it 's a chance for us to do something for hong kong .
hong kong students are not that easily influenced by political parties - they have their own thinking .
some citizens may misunderstand and think our actions may affect hong kong 's safety or might cause economic damage .
but we are so peaceful and we think the solution is for hong kong to be on the road to democracy .
kenneth wong branigan/guardian
hong kong 's stock market fell 1.4 % yesterday on the back of five days of pro-democracy protests .

raymond yeung , a senior economist with anz bank in hong kong , told abc radio national 's breakfast program this morning that a protracted stalemate between the demonstrators and the government would have global ramifications .

documents.title: leung : china 's offer is better than what we have now
text: cnn has this report on cy leung 's national day address , which wrapped up at the great hall earlier this morning .
china had promised hong kong free elections by 2017 , but reneged earlier this year , saying it would allow only approved candidates to stand .

leung told the great hall that china 's offer was still an improvement on the current situation , where hong kong 's leader is chosen by an 1,200-member election committee : hong kong chief executive c.y .
leung , a day after saying this illegal protest will not force the central government to go back on its decision august 31 , said wednesday that people should accept a deal as is .
speaking at a national day reception , leung said , it is understandable that different people may have different ideas about a desirable reform package .
but it is definitely better to have universal suffrage than not .
it is definitely better to have the ( chief executive ) elected by five million eligible voters than by 1,200 people .
and it is definitely better to cast your vote at the polling station than to stay home and watch on television the 1,200 members of the election committee cast their votes .
like other chief executives , leung was n't elected by a popular vote but rather by a 1,200-strong committee stacked with beijing loyalists .
that was set to change in 2017 .
in a way , it will .
leung points out that we will be able to have one-person , one-vote - meaning citizens , not just committee members , can cast ballots .
but as to which candidates they can choose from , the chief executive said that much has been settled and it wo n't change .
i understand this universal suffrage is somewhat different to what the public thinks it would be , he said .
but this is based on the basic law .
we still want to remain peaceful , calm and think what the best is for hong kong .

paul zimmerman , a district councillor , carries a yellow umbrella as hong kong chief executive leung chun-ying ( 6th r ) , shown on a screen , addresses guests at a reception following a flag raising ceremony in hong kong october 1 , 2014 .
yip/reuters

documents.title: hong kong students show support in sydney
text: via aap : students have papered the hong kong government office in sydney with messages urging on the pro-democracy umbrella revolution protesters overseas .

in an action organised on social media , young hong kong natives have surrounded hong kong house in sydney 's cbd to build a mosaic of newspaper clippings and post-it notes bearing messages of solidarity and support .
yellow ribbons , a symbol of democracy and dissent , have also appeared through the railings outside the building .
hong kong for hong kongers !
beijing get lost !
and stop the violence against the peaceful protesters are just some of the messages written on the hundreds of notes stuck to the wall .
keep fighting !
supporting the students from sydney , reads another .
written in chinese and english , the notes range from philosophical statements about the slow march of democracy to exhortations urging the homeland protesters on .
in the past week , hong kong has been rocked by thousands of young people swamping the streets in their push against beijing 's clamp down on elections in the region .
notes in sydney also bear the numbers 689 , a coded reference to the june 1989 tiananmen square student massacres , the memory of which is invoked in these latest student uprisings .
remember tiananmen square !
stand strong for our rights , reads a note .

hong kong house next to sydney 's town hall is the defacto sydney headquarters of the semi-autonomous region , housing the hong kong economic and trade office , trade development council and tourism board .
government officials were away on wednesday celebrating chinese national day .
protesters are due to converge on the chinese consulate in sydney on wednesday for a midday rally .
people write messages of support for pro-democracy protesters in hong kong , on bits of paper to add to the hundreds of others stuck to the wall of hong kong house in central sydney .
gray/reuters
meanwhile , hong kong 's leaders are trying to mark national day as normally as possible inside the great hall : scmp news ( @ scmp news ) 'cheers ! '
cy leung marks national day with champagne .
from this you could n't tell # occupyhongkong is going in we 'll try to get some details of his remarks as soon as they come through .

here 's an update from reuters about this morning 's national day flag-raising ceremony , which some feared could be a flashpoint for clashes between protesters and the hong kong government : underlining nervousness among some activists that provocation on national day could spark violence , hong kong university students made an online appeal not to disturb the flag-raising ceremony that began at 8 a.m. ( midnight gmt ) .
proceedings went ahead peacefully , although scores of students who ringed the ceremony at bauhinia square on the hong kong waterfront booed as the national anthem was played .
hundreds of protesters lined up to view the ceremony , with some organising a human chain to create a buffer between about 100 police at the site and other demonstrators .
a beaming hong kong chief executive leung chun-ying shook hands with supporters waving the chinese flag even as protesters who want him to stand down chanted we want real democracy .
the hong kong and chinese flags billowed in the wind at the completion of the ceremony but one of the main protest groups said they marked the occasion with a heavy heart .
we are not celebrating the 65th anniversary of china .

with the present political turmoil in hong kong and the continued persecution of human rights activists in china , i think today is not a day for celebrations but rather a day of sadness , said oscar lai , a spokesman for the student group scholarism .

chris lau ( @ hkchrislau ) members of scholarism turn their back to raising flags during a ceremony in wan chai heather timmons ( @ heathat ) umbrellas up and boos as the chinese flag is flown by over hk harbor # occupycentral

documents.title: protest photos : guardianwitness
text: scenes from the pro-democracy campaigners third consecutive night on the streets have been submitted to guardianwitness by readers on the scene in hong kong .

user kalokagathia has sent this stirring from a singalong on connaught road : boundless oceans , vast skies classic 90s hong kong rock sing-a-long on connaught road sent via guardian witness by kalokagathia 1 october 2014 , 2:54 user amaryllisnight has this showing the camaraderie among demonstrators : demonstrators help each other to climb over the central reservation as with all other areas of the protest there were many hands to help people wanting to get from one side to the other .
a small group of demonstrators was gather around this gap in the shrubs to give others a helping hand up or down .
in other places people were helping by distributing food , water , masks and ribbons .

sent via guardian witness by amaryllisnight 1 october 2014 , 2:01 some passed the time quietly reading : quietly participating although the majority of the crowds are made up of groups there are a significant number of people here marking their support quietly and solitarily .

sent via guardian witness by amaryllisnight 1 october 2014 , 1:46 others slept : demonstrators resting on a flyover near admiralty sent via guardian witness by amaryllisnight 1 october 2014 , 1:39 all the contributions so far are here .
protests are planned throughout the world on 1 october in solidarity with hong kong 's demonstrators .
here 's when and where they 're planned : worldwide solidarity protests
this is an amazing scene : inside the grand hall , where chief executive cy leung is giving his national day address , a lone yellow umbrella has been opened in the crowd .
rishi iyengar ( @ iyengarrishi ) meanwhile , inside the grand hall , the chief executive begins his speech .
# occupycentral # hongkong @ twitterid it belongs to district councilman paul zimmerman , who tells reporters that hong kong government owes its people an apology .
rishi iyengar ( @ iyengarrishi ) district councilman paul zimmerman is carrying a yellow umbrella and wearing a ribbon in solidarity .
`` hk govt ( 1/2 ) rishi iyengar ( @ iyengarrishi ) owes the people an apology '' # occupycentral # umbrellarevolution # hongkong @ twitterid
my colleague tania branigan has chatted with one of the student leaders behind this movement , joshua wong .

tania branigan ( @ taniabranigan ) joshua wong : `` this scale of civil disobedience is out of my expectation '' tania branigan ( @ taniabranigan ) joshua wong : `` people will organise civil disobedience by themselves , without nfos/political party leaders .
puts more pressure on govt . ''
expect a full report later today .

here 's a video posted a short time ago by the wall street journal , showing protesters braving last night 's inclement weather to keep up their vigil in the streets of admiralty and central , in downtown hong kong .
hong kong protesters sing in the rain
must-read for anybody coming late to this extraordinary story is my colleague jonathan kaiman 's explainer , posted a few hours ago : what 's the story ?
hong kong , one of the world 's most important financial hubs , has exploded into protest .

since sunday night , the so-called umbrella revolution has turned the city 's gleaming central business district into a virtual conflict zone , replete with shouting mobs , police in riot gear , and clouds of tear gas .
tens of thousands of hong kong residents young and old , rich and poor have peacefully occupied major thoroughfares across the city , shuttering businesses and bringing traffic to a halt .
they claim that beijing reneged on an agreement to grant them open elections by 2017 , and demand true universal suffrage .
organisers said on monday that the protest would not end until beijing changes its electoral guidelines and leung chun-ying , the city 's pro-beijing chief executive , steps down .
neither side seems prepared to back off , and nobody knows how the standoff will end .
hong kong protests

documents.title: uk firm sold tear gas to hong kong
text: a few hours ago the guardian reported that a uk company , chemring , has sold crowd-control weapons , including tear gas , to the hong kong government for a number of years .
they 're reviewing their sales policy after sunday 's tear-gas attack on unarmed protesters .
a british company which sold teargas to hong kong has told the guardian it will review its sales policy after a series of attacks on unarmed protesters in the former british colony .
whitehall officials also made it clear they would re-evaluate their policy if they were asked to approve future export licences for teargas to hong kong .
the foreign secretary , philip hammond , said the uk government did not condone the use of cs gas a type of teargas against the protesters .
but he said the canisters being used by the chinese riot police were a legitimate export .
he told the bbc daily politics show : cs gas is available from large numbers of sources around the world .
to be frank , i think that is a rather immaterial point .
they could buy cs gas from the us .
chemring , based in romsey , hampshire , has sold the crowd-control weapon to the former british colony for several years under export licences approved by the british government .
read the full story here a pro-democracy demonstrator gestures after police fired tear gas towards protesters near the hong kong government headquarters on september 28 , 2014 .
olleros/afp/getty images

the flag has been raised , apparently without disruption , just a few shouts from protesters barricaded outside , according to the wsj 's juro osawa : juro osawa ( @ juroosawa ) flag has been raised .
there were some shouts from protesters outside square .
# hongkong # nationalday # occupycentral observers from human rights monitor are on the scene , tweets ryan ho kilpatrick .
ryan ho kilpatrick ( @ chungyingst ) human rights monitor observers @ flag raising ceremony # hkdemocracy # occupycentral # umbrellamovement # occupywanchai
the flag raising ceremony and golden bauhinia square are both important symbols of hong kong 's reunification with china .
the first flag-raising ceremony was held on june 30 , 1997 , when hong kong passed from british control into chinese sovereignty .
at its centre is this statue , given as a gift to hong kong by the beijing government when it took control .
golden bauhinia statue here 's more : the monument serves as a symbol of reunification .
inscriptions in president jiang zemin 's calligraphy can be found at the monument .
hong kong 's sovereignty is symbolized by the white ring around the pinnacle .
meanwhile , the 50 smaller rings denote hong kong 's way of life and the capitalist system that will remain unchanged for another 50 years .
any disruption of the flag-raising ceremony currently underway could be perceived as a separatist gesture - something many protest leaders have been keen to avoid .

the national day flag-raising ceremony appears to have begun without incident in hong kong , despite the throngs of protesters held back from the square by barricades , and some student leaders watching on from the crowd : fion li ( @ fion li ) flag-raising ceremony now as # occupycentral enters into its fourth day leo weese ç® èå° ( @ leoaw ) 8:00am sharp .
pla flyby .
bastien åå¿ .
wai-chung ( @ bwaic ) flags fly over .
guy next to me says to his friend `` try to be happy '' as china anthem plays .
joshua wong is just 17 years old , but has emerged as one of the leaders of this movement .

my colleague jonathan kaiman profiled him earlier : wong , 17 , the razor-thin leader of the student group scholarism , has been one of the city 's most outspoken pro-democracy activists for three years .

wong founded the group in 2011 to protest a beijing-backed proposal to implement a patriotic education curriculum in the city 's public schools ; the following autumn , he mobilised 120,000 people to occupy the city government headquarters , leading officials to shelve the plan .
as a testament to his influence , state media has attempted to discredit him by portraying him as an extremist with shadowy ties to the us ( he firmly denies the charge ) .
police arrested him on friday night after a group of students scaled a fence to invade the government complex .
by the time they released him on sunday afternoon , his detention had already catalyzed further demonstrations .
despite his age , wong is known as a political firebrand : you have to see every battle as possibly the final battle , he told cnn recently .
only then will you have the determination to fight .

the wall street journal 's fiona law has just tweeted that wong has arrived at the flag ceremony and managed to get into golden bauhinia square : fiona law ( @ law fiona ) student activist leader joshua wong arrives flag ceremony .
he says a taxi drove him there for free # occupycentral fiona law ( @ law fiona ) scholarism members smoothly get into flag ceremony .
`` question is whether i 'll be escorted out . ''
# occupycentral
the national day flag raising ceremony is set to begin in golden bauhinia square in about 15 minutes .
the square is only a few minutes away from the e of the protests , but demonstrators are being stopped from attending .
tensions are building : fiona law ( @ law fiona ) scholarism 's oscar lai , before flag ceremony , says he 's deleting contacts on mobile to protect others in case of arrest .

# occupycentral tania branigan ( @ taniabranigan ) groups arriving to attend flag raising - protestors remain outside leo weese ç® èå° ( @ leoaw ) protesters here have no ability to stop people from entering , it 's much more a symbolic act .
the flag will be raised .
my colleague tania branigan is currently down at hong kong 's golden bauhinia square , where protesters are trying to reach the national day flag raising ceremony .

she sends along these snaps : large but good tempered crowd at barriers which have stopped them reaching golden bauhinia square for the national day flag raising ceremony branigan/guardian protestors near golden bauhinia square : fight for democracy peacefully- do n't crush the police , a speaker urges .
branigan/guardian

here 's the latest dispatch from my colleague tania branigan , who is on the streets of downtown hong kong : protest leaders and hong kong government refuse to budge pro-democracy protest leaders in hong kong and the region 's government refused to budge as a critical day approached for the mass demonstrations .

tens of thousands packed the city 's downtown areas for a third night on tuesday , chanting we love hong kong and giving new meaning to the nickname umbrella revolution as they stood through a thunderstorm .
previously they used them to ward off teargas and shelter from the sun .
organisers warned they would step up their actions if the region 's chief executive did not meet them by midnight on tuesday .
wednesday is china 's national day which celebrates the foundation of the people 's republic by the communist party and a public holiday , meaning more people will be free to protest .

a spokesperson for the student group scholarism said members would try to attend the flag-raising ceremony at golden bauhinia square in the morning , but would not chant slogans or seek conflict if they were allowed in .

read the full story here crowds of pro-democracy protestors gather in the rain in the mongkok district of kowloon , as pro-democracy protests spread away from the central business district of hong kong .
30 sep 2014 /rex

documents.title: hong kong pro-democracy protests face crucial day
text: welcome to our rolling coverage of hong kong 's pro-democracy demonstrations , now in their sixth day .

it promises to be a crucial one , as the sun rises on china 's national day holiday , with protesters and the hong kong government locked in a stalemate over the future of the region 's chief executive , cy leung , and beijing 's bid to vet future leadership candidates .

here 's where we stand : as dawn broke in hong kong wednesday , thousands of protesters who had spent the night in the streets despite heavy rains prepared to mark national day , a major holiday across china , with new demonstrations .
the protesters ' continued presence in the streets was a rebuke to hong kong chief executive cy leung , who had called on them to leave .
beijing said it supported the local government .
we fully believe in and support the hong kong sar government to deal with this issue , a foreign ministry spokesperson said .
protest organizers have reported receiving death threats .
the police presence in the streets remained light .
protesters vowed to stay in the streets , although some leaders expressed concerns about a potential backlash to a prolonged sit-in .
see a gallery of readers ' of the historic protests .
interviews with protesters : what they want .
some of the teargas fired by the authorities in hong kong could have been supplied by british companies .
the protests comprise multiple organizations with many leaders and many protesters seem unaffiliated .
read a who 's who of the protest leadership .
catch up on our earlier coverage here .
my colleague tania branigan ( @ taniabranigan ) is on the ground in hong kong and jonathan kaiman ( @ jrkaiman ) is in beijing .
get in touch with me at @ twitterid

key_events.text:
7.26pm BST
19:26
US and China air differences on Hong Kong

4.13pm BST
16:13
Chinese state media describes 'threat' from protests

2.33pm BST
14:33
Chris Patten condemns handling of the protests

bulletin.text: Second day of public holiday dawns.
Are you there? Submit to GuardianWitness.
